title: 103_s1049
content:
The "Lechuguilla Cave Protection Act of 1993" recognizes the scientific and environmental significance of Lechuguilla Cave and other caves in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. It aims to protect these caves from adverse effects of mineral exploration and development. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS

Cave protection area - lands within the area depicted on the map in section 4(b).
Secretary - Secretary of the Interior.
Other terms - terms have the same meaning as in the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976.

SEC. 4. LAND WITHDRAWAL. The public lands within the cave protection area, totaling approximately 6,280 acres, are withdrawn from all forms of appropriation or disposal under public land laws. The lands are described in a map filed in April 1993. The Secretary will publish a notice with the legal description in the Federal Register. The Secretary will publish a notice in the Federal Register with the legal description of the withdrawn lands. The detailed map and legal description will have the same force as if included in the Act, with the Secretary allowed to correct errors. Copies of the map and legal description will be available for public inspection. The public lands withdrawn under subsection (a) shall be managed by the Secretary through the Director of the Bureau of Land Management, in accordance with relevant laws including the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT OF EXISTING LEASES. The Secretary will not allow new drilling on valid mineral or geothermal leases within the withdrawn lands to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources of Carlsbad Caverns National Park. Activities on existing leases may be suspended if necessary to prevent adverse impacts. During the prohibition period, new drilling is not allowed on valid mineral or geothermal leases within withdrawn lands to protect cave resources. The Secretary will seek agreements for termination of existing leases if necessary to prevent adverse impacts. During the prohibition period, the Secretary will seek agreements with leaseholders to terminate or restrict activities on valid mineral or geothermal leases within withdrawn lands to protect cave resources, including Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources of Carlsbad Caverns National Park. The agreements will consider the value of oil and gas resources that will not be recovered or produced. If no agreement is reached by the end of the specified period, further actions may be taken. The Secretary will take steps to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park if no agreement is reached with leaseholders. This may include acquiring lands covered by the lease, which will be managed according to relevant laws. The Secretary will seek cooperation from the State of New Mexico and other landowners in the cave protection area to implement restrictions for the protection of Lechuguilla Cave and other resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park. SEC. 6. ADDITIONAL PROTECTION AND RELATION TO OTHER LAWS. The Secretary will take additional steps to protect Lechuguilla Cave and other significant cave resources in Carlsbad Caverns National Park, including limiting access and prohibiting removal of resources for scientific purposes. The Secretary may permit the removal of mineral, geological, or cave resources for scientific purposes. If existing laws are insufficient to protect Lechuguilla Cave or other significant cave resources, the Secretary will seek additional authority from relevant committees. This Act does not affect any party's ability to seek legal recourse. The Act does not limit parties from seeking compensation under other laws, such as the Tucker Act, or prevent the United States from using defenses or claims in compensation actions.
